awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Undergraduate Astronomy Research and Education through Observation of Jupiter Impact Flashes to Characterize Small-Body Populations in the Outer Solar System
awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation uses the Early-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) funding mechanism to support exploratory work in its early stages on untested, but potentially transformative, research ideas or approaches. This EAGER project was awarded as a result of the invitation in the Dear Colleague Letter NSF 16-080 to proposers from Historically Black Colleges and Universities to submit proposals that would strengthen research capacity of faculty at the institution. The project at Hampton University aims to detect flashes caused by small objects impacting the giant planet Jupiter. As demonstrated by recent impacts recorded by amateur astronomers, the intensity of impact flashes indicates the size of the impactors; if enough flashes are observed, the measurements will reveal the size distribution of those impactors. This in turn can help understand how the outer solar system has evolved since its formation. The project will facilitate installing a roof-top observatory, in which a telescope will be operated by a team of undergraduate students who will take charge of conducting the Jovian impact survey. The roof-top observatory will also enable the university to host outreach events for local students from elementary and high schools as well as the general public.

The project's objective is to measure the size distribution of Jovian impactors, which are thought to be members of the Jupiter Family Comets (JFC) that originate beyond Neptune's orbit. Most JFCs are too dim for direct telescopic observation from Earth, so the project will observe Jupiter impacts to measure the sizes of objects that are otherwise impossible to observe. If the JFC size distribution shows signs of numerous collisions in the past, it would be consistent with the hypothesis that Uranus and Neptune violently migrated outward early in the solar system history and scattered primordial planetesimal objects. If the JFC population contains more small fragments than expected from collisions, it would reveal that most comets eventually break up during their repeated close encounters with the sun. If the JFC population contains few small objects, it would indicate that at least some JFCs have been left undisturbed since the formation of the solar system. The main technical challenge here is to detect a sufficient number of impacts to build a statistically significant size distribution. The goal of the current exploratory project is to reduce uncertainties regarding the number of impacts per year to enable a larger impact survey in the future.

This EAGER project is co-funded by the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of the current project was to develop a method and capability to persistently observe Jupiter to detect flashes caused by small objects impacting the giant planet, and to conduct such observations to demonstrate the newly developed capability. Such observations are scientifically valuable because the intensity of those impact flashes indicates the size of the impactors; if enough flashes are systematically observed, the measurements will reveal the size distribution of those impactors, which will help us understand how the outer solar system has evolved since its formation.

Thus, the highest-priority intellectual merit accomplishment enabled by the current award is the successful capture of 40 hours of video-frame-rate Jupiter data over the course o f a single intense observing season by a team of undergraduate students at Hampton University. Successfully capturing 48 hours of video-frame-rate Jupiter data during a single season represents one of the most extensive systematic Jupiter observing campaigns ever conducted to date. The captured data were also analyzed to search for impact flashes; although our analyses so far have not detected any flash in the captured data, the data are archived so that they may be analyzed in the future using improved techniques. Our project thus demonstrated that we have developed, tested and implemented the observing techniques appropriate for Jupiter impact detection. An annotated image of Jupiter is attached to demonstrate the quality of images captured during our observing campaign.

The highest-priority broader impact accomplishment is in advancing the careers of 4 undergraduate and 1 postbaccalaureate researchers at Hampton University, a Historically Black University (HBCU). The 4 undergraduate students were recruited from Hampton University?s engineering and physics programs. The award created a valuable research opportunity for the student researchers. Remarkably, all five of the researchers supported by the current award leveraged their research experience and advanced to graduate schools to pursue PhDs: 3 in engineering, 1 in astronomy, and 1 in physical oceanography. An attached photograph shows the participants of the 2018 Jupiter Observation campaign, including the 4 undergraduate researchers.

Another broader impact accomplishment is that the award was leveraged to expand the research infrastructure at Hampton University. In particular, the current award enabled the installation of a permanently mounted 15-inch Schmidt Cassegrain telescope housed in a 12-ft clam-shell dome bolted on the roof-top instrumentation deck of the Turner Natural Science Building on the Hampton University campus. Both the telescope and the dome are computerized and operated from an adjacent control room in the building. The installation establishes a permanent astronomical observation capability at Hampton University that can be available for both research and education. Attached photographs depict the telescope and dome configuration.

In addition, the current award facilitated a new citizen science project. The activities at Hampton University supported by current award led to the development of a new partnership with the Back Bay Amateur Astronomers (BBAA) Inc., a local amateur astronomy non-profit organization. Members of BBAA significantly contributed their experience and efforts in developing, testing, and implementing Jupiter observing techniques appropriate for impact detections. The extensive collective experience of BBAA members in commercially available astronomical equipment also guided the configuration of the Hampton University observatory. The members of BBAA also created a web page that outlines how to conduct observations to search for Jovian impact flashes, and members collectively captured over 480 hours of Jupiter monitoring data since 2018. The data captured by the BBAA were also made available to the researchers at Hampton University for future analyses.

The establishment of a permanent astronomical observatory at Hampton University on a highly prominent location on campus also raises the research profile of the university. As a top HBCU, Hampton University often hosts high-profile visitors who tour our research facilities, and the newly established observatory enabled by the current award is now a highlight of such visits. For example, in September 2021, the US Vice President Kamala Harris toured the observatory in an effort to underscore the importance of investing in the research and education infrastructure at HBCUs. The Vice President?s facebook post of the day featured the observatory dome as illustrated in an attached photograph. The increased visibility of research infrastructure such as this astronomical observatory will help to broaden participation in STEM fields.
